title-group.article-title: Using vibration phase space topology changes for structural damage detection

article-meta.aff: 1College of Science & Engineering, Jinan University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China
2School of Civil and Resource Engineering, The University of Western Australia, Crawley, Perth, WA, Australia
3The Key Laboratory of Disaster Forecast and Control in Engineering, Ministry of Education of China, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China

author-notes.corresp: Hongwei Ma, College of Science & Engineering, Jinan University, No. 601 West Huang Pu Road, Guangzhou 510632, Guangdong, China Email: tmahw@jnu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Ideally, structural health monitoring of civil infrastructure consists of determining, by measured parameters, the location and severity of damage in the structure. Many structural vibration parameters have been used to identify and quantify damage. Using parameters based on structural vibration phase space features for damage detection is a new field in structural health monitoring. In this article, a new parameter based on topology changes of the phase space of vibration signals is proposed to identify structural damage, and an index named changes of phase space topology derived from vibration time history is used to locate the damage. A circular arch structure is used to demonstrate the method. Both numerical simulation and experimental tests of dynamic responses of a scaled arch structure to impact loads are carried out. The obtained structural response data are used to detect structural damage. Both the experimental and numerical results indicate that this method can successfully locate damage. It also demonstrated that this proposed method is more sensitive to damage but less sensitive to noise than modal-based parameters. The proposed damage index can be a good candidate in an online structural health monitoring system, as it depends on global vibration measurements but is more sensitive to structural damage than other global vibration-based parameters such as vibration frequencies and mode shapes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Intensive research study has been carried out to develop reliable methods to monitor structural conditions owing to their tremendous potential for life-safety and/or economic benefits in structural asset management. Damage detection has applications to almost all engineered structures and mechanical systems including those associated with all types of defense hardware, civil infrastructure, manufacturing equipment, and commercial aerospace systems. Damage identification is carried out in conjunction with five closely related disciplines that include damage detection, classification of damage severity, determination of the location of damage, prediction of possible breakdown or failure, and estimation of the remaining service life, as summarized within the theme issue in Refs 1 and 2. Damage detection is the first level of the more general problem of damage identification.

Structural health monitoring (SHM) is associated with online-global damage identification in structural systems such as aircraft and buildings, which is the most important in these five disciplines. Vibration-based SHM has arisen as one possible approach to the problem of structural damage identification and localization. The structure of interest is excited through either ambient or applied loading. The resulting structural vibrations are measured and analyzed for structural condition monitoring and damage identification through comparison of the changes of various structural vibration parameters before and after structural damage. Much of the research in this field has therefore focused on the problem of vibration parameter extraction and establishment of relations between the vibration parameter changes with the structural conditions. Ideally, the chosen parameter should be sensitive to structural condition changes but insensitive to measurement noises and structural modeling errors. Then, through analyzing the changes in the chosen structural vibration parameter or parameters, the structural damage can be located and quantified. Many signal processing techniques have been developed for reliably extracting the structural vibration parameters, and many vibration parameters are tested for their suitability in identifying structural damages. The most commonly used vibration parameters for structural damage identification are frequencies,3,4 mode shapes, and mode shape–related parameters such as modal assurance criterion (MAC), coordinate modal assurance criteria (COMAC),5 flexibility,6 and mode shape derivatives.7,8 An overview of these studies can be found in Refs 2, 9, and 10. In general, frequencies of a structure can be easily and reliably measured at a few points in vibration test. Therefore, structural vibration frequency is a good parameter for real-time SHM. However, structural vibration frequencies are not sensitive enough to small damages. Structural damages cause changes in structural vibration mode shapes as well as natural frequencies. Mode shape changes are often more sensitive to damages than frequencies, but to identify local structural damages, high modes are often needed, which are less accurately measured. It also requires more number of sensors for the measurements, which make the vibration measurements more expensive. Mode shape–related parameters, such as curvature of the mode shape,7 COMAC,5 and flexibility,6 appear to be more sensitive to loss of stiffness due to member damage than the mode shapes themselves. However, these mode shape–related parameters require even more measurement points in order to be reliably estimated. For these reasons, mode shape and mode shape–related parameters are not suitable to real-time SHM as these methods are not only costly but also difficult to maintain many sensors and to process a large amount of real-time vibration data. Besides modal parameter–related methods, a number of other methods have also been studied for structural condition monitoring. These include the wavelet-based approach,11,12 Hilbert–Huang Transform (HHT) method,13 autoregressive moving average (ARMA)14 method, frequency response reference functions (FRRF) method,15 autoregressive exogenous input (ARX) frequency domain model,16 etc. These signal processing methods have been intensively studied in the last decade. For example, the wavelet method performs a time–frequency analysis of the measured structural vibration signal and provides more detailed information about nonstationary signals which traditional Fourier analysis misses.11,12 The time series–based approaches that directly use the measured vibration time histories, therefore avoiding modal parameters identification, are also intensively researched and commonly used in structural damage identification.17–20

Recently, a novel nonlinear structural damage detection methods based on chaos were proposed.21 Nonlinear dynamic methods offer another possibility to use the measured vibration response for structural damage identification. Most nonlinear signal analysis methods operate in the phase space. Such methods are relatively new and insufficiently explored for structural dynamics and SHM, but the existing research proves their capabilities and potential.21,22 The previous studies21,22 explored the possibility of using the changes in the phase space geometry/distribution of the dynamic response of the structure before and after damage for damage detection. Based on the changes in phase geometry, a new class of damage indices is developed in Refs 23–29 to identify structural conditions. These indices are based on a generic phase space description of the dynamic responses and do not depend on any underlying system model. Rather, the vibration data themselves are used to build a reference model of the “healthy” structure. Subsequent analysis is made with respect to the reference model for damage identification. In the study by Nichols et al.,30 a damage index defined based on the average local attractor variance ratio (ALAVR) of the response attractor in the state space is extracted to quantify the damage of an example aluminum beam. The results demonstrate that this index is more sensitive to damage than the modal-based parameters. In subsequent studies,31,32 chaotic excitation is used to minimize the influence of noise in the measured vibration data and to improve the sensitivity and robustness of the state space–based indices extracted from the structural responses for structural damage detection. Another class of indices defined for structural damage detection based on the phase space of the attractor is the correlation dimension of the response attractors.33 All the above-mentioned studies demonstrated the robustness and sensitivity of the indices defined from phase space parameters for structural damage detection. However, all the above approaches require to excite the structure in question with a prescribed chaotic input signals, which is almost impossible for a real civil infrastructure. To overcome this limitation, Nichols34 explored the use of ambient excitation and empirical modeling with phase space–based approach in detecting and quantifying damages in offshore structures. Overbey et al.35 use state space–based prediction error methods with stochastic excitation for SHM. Pakrashi et al.36 use the wavelet transformed phase space of the responses to identify the damage of a bridge model under a moving vehicle load. These researches34–36 prove that the phase space–based approach can also be used to identify structural conditions without chaotic excitation. It should be noted that all the above reviewed phase space–based nonlinear approaches can successfully identify the damage existence, and some of them can also quantify the damage, but none of them are used to locate the damage. Locating damage is very important in SHM.

In this article, a new parameter based on topology changes of the phase space of vibration signals is proposed to identify structural damage, and an index named changes of phase space topology (CPST) derived from vibration time history is used to locate the damage. The phase space reconstruction using delay coordinate approach is introduced first. To demonstrate the method, dynamic responses of a circular arch are simulated using commercial software ANSYS. The simulated dynamic responses are used to identify the structural conditions. It is demonstrated that as compared with the various modal-based parameters, the proposed method in this study is more sensitive to structural damage. To further demonstrate the method, a scaled circular arch was also built and tested in the laboratory. The dynamic test data are used to identify the structural conditions. Both the experimental and numerical results demonstrate that the proposed method can successfully identify the damage existence and locate single damage (SD) and multiple damages (MDs) in the structure. The proposed damage index is more sensitive to damage than modal-based parameters. Like vibration frequencies, the damage index in the current proposed phase space–based method can be calculated using dynamic response measured at a single point, and the proposed damage index is more sensitive to structural damage than vibration frequency; therefore, it can be effectively used in real-time continuous SHM systems.

sec.title: Modal-based damage detection
sec.p:
Modal-based damage detection methods have been intensively studied. For comparison, they are also applied in this study to identify structural conditions. A scaled circular arch structure as shown in Figure 1, which is common in long-span roof and bridge structures, is used as an example structure in the present study. The physical properties of the circular arch model considered are as follows: density
ρ = 7 . 85 ×
10
3
kg
/
m
3
, Young’s modulus
E = 200
GPa
, and Poisson’s ratio v = 0.28. The dimension of model is chosen as follows: cross section is
25 × 9
mm
2
, the arch angle is 90°, and radius to the centroid of the arch cross section is R = 500 mm. Boundary condition is chosen to be hinged at both ends. Commercial software ANSYS is used in numerical simulations. The arch is modeled with eight-node solid elements (element solid 45 in ANSYS). In order to model cracks in the structure, fine elements are used, with a total of 320 elements along the tangential direction, 4 elements in the width direction, and 10 elements in the thickness direction, as shown in Figure 2. Crack damage at the bottom surface is assumed occurring near the 1/4 span of the arch structure. It is simulated by not connecting the two adjacent elements, indicating a very fine crack with its width negligible. A total of four damage levels are assumed with the crack depth equal to 10%, 20%, 30%, and 40% of the cross-sectional depth, respectively. Using modal analysis, the first four frequencies and mode shapes of the intact and damaged arch are obtained. The first four intact mode shapes are shown in Figure 3, and the first four frequencies corresponding to the different damage levels are given in Table 1. It can be observed that the natural frequencies reduce with the damage development, except for that of the Mode 3, which has no change because the damage is located near the stationary point of this mode.

caption.p: A scaled circular arch structure model.
Finite element model of the circular arch structure and the locations of measurement points and damage for modal-based method in numerical analysis.
First four mode shapes of the undamaged arch structure obtained from the modal analysis.
First four natural frequencies (hertz) of the arch structure at different damage levels

sec.p: As can be noted that reduction of the first modal frequency corresponding to the four damage levels is −0.26%, −0.80%, −1.85%, and −3.43%, respectively, and that of the fourth modal frequency is −0.11%, −0.37%, −0.80%, and −1.5%, respectively. It has been reported that changing environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity might lead to more significant changes in vibration frequencies as those listed earlier.37 Moreover, changing ambient loading conditions, equipment noise, and so on might all cause variations in structural vibration frequencies, and these changes in vibration frequencies might be more significant than that corresponding to a 40% crack depth. Therefore, although vibration frequencies are easily measured, they cannot be confidently used alone to monitor structural conditions as they are not sensitive enough to localized structural damages.

sec.title: Mode shape curvature method
sec.p: Mode shape curvature is a parameter that has been studied and found more sensitive to structural damage than frequencies.7 In formulating the eigenvalue problem, Pandey et al.7 assumed that structural damage only affects the stiffness matrix and not the mass matrix. For the undamaged condition, the eigenvalue problem is expressed as

where the superscript d represents the stiffness matrix,
λ
i
d
the ith eigenvalue, and
Φ
i
d
the ith eigenvector of the damaged structure. The pre- and postdamage eigenvectors are the basis for damage detection. Mode shape curvature for the beam in the undamaged and damaged conditions can then be estimated numerically from the displacement mode shapes. Given the undamaged and damaged mode shapes, consider a beam cross section at location x subjected to a bending moment
M ( x )
, the curvature,
v ″ ( x )
, is given by

where E is the modulus of elasticity and I is the moment of inertia of the section. Thus, for a given moment applied to the damaged and undamaged structure, a reduction of stiffness associated with damage will, in turn, lead to an increase in curvature. Therefore, an estimation of the extent of damage can be obtained by measuring the amount of change in the mode shape curvatures.38 Generally, the damaged mode shape curvatures are subtracted by intact one to calculate the difference in order to assess the damage.

sec.title: COMAC and enhanced coordinate modal assurance criteria
sec.p: Based on mode shape changes, another parameter used for damage detection is MAC. However, while MAC can detect damage existence, it cannot directly detect the location of the structural damage.39 Researchers improved the method and developed COMAC and enhanced coordinate modal assurance criteria (ECOMAC), which can detect both damage existence and location.5,40 These damage indicators are briefly presented here. COMAC and ECOMAC are defined as5,8

where
ϕ
i
u
(
j )
and
ϕ
i
d
(
j )
are the jth nodal displacement before and after damage, respectively, and n is the mode orders. According to changes in the COMAC and ECOMAC values, the damage location can be identified.

sec.title: Change in flexibility method
sec.p: Pandey and Biswas6 proposed another indicator using the dynamically measured flexibility matrix to estimate the changes in the static behavior of the structure. Because the flexibility matrix F is defined as the inverse of the static stiffness matrix, it relates the applied static force f and resulting structural displacement u as
The expression of the flexibility matrix is written as

where
[ ϕ ]
is the mode shape matrix and
ϕ
i
is the ith mode shape. The diagonal matrix of rigidity
[ Ω ]
corresponds to
ω
i
2
, where
ω
i
is the ith frequency. Thus, each column of the flexibility matrix represents the displacement pattern of the structure associated with a unit force applied at the associated degree of freedom. Measuring the flexibility matrices before and after damage, the variation matrix
[ Δ ]
can be obtained by

where
[ F ]

F

]
are flexibility matrices before and after damage, respectively. For each column of matrix
[ Δ ]
, let
δ
¯
j
be the absolute maximum value of the elements in the jth column, that is,
δ
¯

|

, i = 1 , 2 , … , n
, in which
δ

are elements of matrix
[ Δ ]
and represent the flexibility variation in each degree of freedom. The column of the flexibility matrix corresponding to the largest
δ
¯
j
is indicative of the degree of freedom where the maximum variation in flexibility has been produced or the location of the damage.41

sec.title: Numerical result analysis
sec.p: Using the mode shapes presented in Figure 3, the mode shape–related damage indicators presented earlier are calculated to identify damage. Figure 4 shows the results corresponding to the different indicators. The damage location is marked by a red arrow in Figure 4.

caption.p: Mode shape–based damage indicators under different damage levels: (a) difference of first mode shape curvature, (b) COMAC, (c) ECOMAC, and (d) flexibility change.
COMAC: coordinate modal assurance criteria; ECOMAC: enhanced coordinate modal assurance criteria.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 4, except COMAC, the other three mode shape–based indicators successfully identify the damage with a relatively larger value corresponding to the damage location. The respective damage indicator also increases with the damage severity. COMAC method failed to successfully locate the damage. The minimum COMAC values occur near the true damage location, but they are larger than 0.995, indicating that the damage cannot be identified because in real test, inevitable noise usually will result in the COMAC value of undamaged structure less than 0.99. The changes in ECOMAC and flexibility successfully identify the damage, but false damage identifications also occur, especially there are a number of peaks in the ECOMAC value, which very likely lead to false damage identifications. The mode shape curvature difference gives the best identification. However, it should be noted that these results are obtained with theoretical continuous mode shape functions, and the difference is very small, in an order of 10-3e as shown in Figure 4(a). In reality, not only the measurement noise inevitably exists, but also the measured mode shapes will not be that smooth as it requires very dense sensor array, which are likely to result in errors in the calculated mode shape curvature difference.

To examine the capability of these methods with less number of sensors, assume there are only 17 measurement points along the arc length of the example arch structure, as shown in Figure 2, and the mode shapes are extracted based on these 17 measurements. The first four mode shapes are shown in Figure 5. These mode shapes are used to calculate the four mode shape–based damage indicators and the results are given in Figure 6.

caption.p: First four mode shapes of the undamaged arch model using 17 measurement points.
Mode shape–based damage indicator using 17 measurement points: (a) difference of first mode curvature, (b) COMAC, (c) ECOMAC, and (d) flexibility change.
COMAC: coordinate modal assurance criteria; ECOMAC: enhanced coordinate modal assurance criteria.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 6(a) and (d), the difference of first mode curvature and flexibility can still identify the damage location, but the ECOMAC fails to confidentially identify the damage. These results demonstrate that with less measurement points, even the data are noise free, the confidence of mode shape–based indicators in identifying structural damage decreases. This is because they are not very sensitive to small damage, and their sensitivity further reduces when the measurement points are less and are away from the damage locations. Further discussion on relative sensitivities will be given later in this article.

In SHM of civil infrastructure, with the influence of measurement noises and changing ambient loads from wind, temperature, humidity, etc., mode parameters might not be accurately identified using limited sensors. These in turn may result in the mode shape–based indices not able to detect structural damage. To demonstrate this, the first four mode shapes are smeared with 0.5% normal distributed noise, as shown in Figure 7. The above analyses are repeated using these noise-contaminated mode shapes. The results corresponding to the mode shape–related damage indicators are shown in Figure 8. As shown, with the existence of only 0.5% noise in the mode shape, none of the four mode shape–based damage indices can successfully identify the assumed crack damage in the example arch structure. This is because the assumed crack damage is very thin. Although its depth is significant compared to the structure thickness, it has insignificant effect on vibration mode shape. Because the influence of noise is more prominent than the changes caused by crack damage, it makes the damage undetectable using the noise-contaminated mode shape data.

caption.p: First four mode shapes of the undamaged arch model using 17 measurement points after smeared with 0.5% noise.
Mode shape–based damage indicators using 17 measurement points with the mode shapes smeared with 0.5% noise: (a) difference of first mode curvature, (b) COMAC, (c) ECOMAC, and (d) flexibility change.
COMAC: coordinate modal assurance criteria; ECOMAC: enhanced coordinate modal assurance criteria.

sec.p: Moreover, it should be noted that a larger number of measurements are needed to reliably extract the structural vibration mode shapes, which makes the mode shape–related indices not as efficient as vibration frequencies for application in continuous online structural condition monitoring. In theory, a single measurement is sufficient to extract structural vibrations. As will be demonstrated later, the proposed index in this study based on vibration phase space change can also be extracted from a single measurement, but is more sensitive to structural damage than vibration frequencies.

sec.title: Concept of phase space
sec.p: A phase space is a space in which all possible states of a dynamic system are represented, with each possible state of the system corresponding to one unique point in the phase space. For mechanical systems, the phase space usually consists of all possible values of position (displacement) and momentum (velocity) variables. A plot of position and momentum variables as a function of time is a phase plot or a phase diagram. In a phase space, every degree of freedom or parameter of the system is represented as an axis of a multidimensional space; a one-dimensional system is called a phase line, while a two-dimensional system is called a phase plane. For every possible state of the system, or allowed combination of values of the system’s parameters, a point is plotted in the multidimensional space. The phase diagram represents all that the system can be, and its shape can easily elucidate the qualities of the system that might not be obvious otherwise.

In a dynamic system, the response time series is the comprehensive reflection of interaction of many physical factors. It contains all the information of variables in the dynamic system that will vary when one of the factors changes. However, the information buried in the time series is not straightforward to be extracted from directly analyzing the time history. On the other hand, the reconstructed phase space can do well. Therefore, it could be used as a good candidate parameter for structural damage identification.

sec.title: Phase space reconstruction
sec.p: The phase space reconstruction stems from the dynamical system approach for analysis of nonlinear time series. The main idea of this approach is to equip the investigator with tools for analysis and modeling of a system from observed time-dependent variables. The application of such an approach for a vibrating system will give us the possibility to reconstruct its dynamic behavior from the measured vibration response. This approach can also be used in the linear vibration. The phase space (attractor) can be reconstructed from the response of a dynamical system expressed as

The state of the system at any point in time is specified by the vector x in d-dimensional phase space. An initial condition x(0) will, under the action of F, asymptotically approach the system’s dynamical attractor, a subset of phase space that may be thought of as a geometric object to which all trajectories belong. It is often problematic to experimentally measure each of the state variables. If the system of equations is unattainable, the qualitative dynamics of the attractor may still be reconstructed from a single measured coordinate, based on the theorem proposed by Takens.42 The delay coordinate approach is used to reconstruct the attractor in this fashion. This approach takes properly delayed copies of the single, discretely measured time series to represent the m coordinates of the reconstructed phase space. Consequently, a point at time n can be expressed as

where the delayed copies of x(n) are often referred to as the pseudostate vectors. A successful reconstruction requires the choice of both delay T and embedding dimension m. T must be large enough because if the delay is too small the resulting vectors will be nearly the same and each will be carrying a great deal of redundant information. As T→ 0, the vectors will, in fact, be the same and the resulting attractor will be collapsed onto the 45° line in phase space. As a simple illustration, consider a particle whose position described by a sinusoid
x ( t ) = A
sin ( ω t )
. The velocity,
υ =
x
·
= A ω cos ( ω t )
, is just a delayed version of position with delay
T = π / 2 ω
. The choice of m is equally critical, given that too small a dimension will result in trajectories not unique. For example, consider a simple harmonic oscillator described by a position and a velocity. The phase space description of this system is a circle in the phase plane requiring two coordinates to describe its geometry. If this system is embedded in one dimension (described by one coordinate), the phase space representation would be a line. On the other hand, too large an m will result in additional computational cost by requiring
m + ε
dimensions,
ε
is the increment of dimension m, to unfold an m dimensional attractor. With appropriate T and m, the dynamics of the system can be unfolded well by a phase space. The method of choosing appropriate T and m is described in Ref. 43.

For the purpose of this investigation, which is restricted to damage detection rather than a full reconstruction of the vibrating structure, a dimension
m = 2
is used because it will preserve some of the properties of the vibrating system and will be possible to observe changes introduced by damage in it. The choice of delay T will be discussed later.

sec.title: Proposed damage index
sec.p: To locate and quantify damage, an index, named CPST, is proposed. The phase trajectory as defined by equation (9) of the responses corresponding to the undamaged structure is considered as the base trajectory. Similarly, when the structure suffers damage, a new set of data

are collected in the same way. The object of the feature-based damage identification is to extract some metric capable of discriminating between the base trajectory (undamaged) set X and damaged dataset Y. In this article, the dimension m is selected to be 2. Hence, the coordinator of pristine phase space from time series can be described as

where N is the length of time series, k = Tfs is the number of point sampled in the delay T, and fs is the sampling frequency. A fiducial point on the trajectory corresponding to the damaged structure is selected with time index r as Y(r). The nearest p neighbors of this point are then selected on the base trajectory (pristine) as

where p denotes the nearest neighbors to fiducial point and the
‖ · ‖
operator computes the Euclidean norm. Note the time indices of the neighbors need not have any relation in time to the fiducial point as the search is made based on the Euclidean norm only. The future value of Y(r) at time steps s into the future may then be forecasted using the baseline data as the model via

where the predicted value
Y
^
is the average of the values at the neighborhoods of time step s. Then, the damage index CPST is defined as

where Y(r+s) is the averaged values for fiducial point defined in equation (13). This calculation will be performed N−k times because the reconstructed phase trajectory has N−k points. If a structure is damaged, the value of the CPST will increase. This method stems from Ref. 24, which used the phase space of the chaotic attractor to identify the changes of the dynamic system. The proposed method makes some changes for effectively adapting the linear vibration system, such as the selection of delay T as compared to that in Ref. 24. More discussions regarding the changes will be discussed later. In this article, the total number of neighborhood points, p, is selected to be 15 and s is selected to be 2. A schematic view of the above described calculations is shown in Figure 9.

caption.p: Schematic view of CPST calculations.
CPST: changes of phase space topology.

sec.title: Damage detection using phase space method based on numerical data
sec.p: In order to demonstrate the proposed method, using the transient analysis method, the dynamic strain responses of the same circular arch as in the modal-based analysis under different damage scenarios subjected to an impact force are simulated. The dynamic responses at the same 17 measurement points with a sampling frequency of 2000 Hz are calculated and used in the analysis for damage identification. To study the robustness of this approach in a noise-contaminated environment, the response time histories smeared with Gaussian noise of different levels are also used in the analyses. The damage scenarios of the arch are shown in Table 2. Both SD and MD are considered. The damage locations are shown in Figure 10. It should be noted that the assumed damage on the left of the arch structure is the same as the one considered earlier in section “Modal-based damage detection.” In MD scenarios, the left damage is assumed to be 40%, that is, the crack depth is 40% of the beam thickness, while the damage on the right changes in different damage cases as listed in Table 2.

caption.p: Damage scenarios setting

fn.p: SD: single damage; MD: multiple damage.

caption.p: Finite element model of the circular arch structure and the locations of measurement points and damages.

sec.title: SD detection
sec.p: Figure 11(a) and (c) shows the typical simulated response time histories at measurement point 5 without and with 10% noise. The corresponding power spectral functions are shown in Figure 11(b) and (d). The power spectrums indicate that vibration Mode 1 dominates the arch responses. This information is very important in choosing the time delay in phase space reconstruction. The power spectrum of response time series of undamaged structure indicates that the first frequency is 113.6 Hz, which is the same as the modal analysis presented in “Modal-based damage detection.” Hence, a time delay T = 1/(4 × 113.6) s is used to calculate the phase space response. Using the method described earlier, the time series without noise or smeared with 1%, 5%, 10%, and 15% noise are reconstructed into phase space. It should be noted that if the selected time delay for phase space reconstruction is too small, as shown in Figure 12(a), or too large, as shown in Figure 12(b), the phase space will shrink to a line. The typical reconstructed phase spaces using the time delay determined according to the fundamental vibration period as described earlier are shown in Figure 13. It can be observed that the difference of the topology of the phase spaces between pristine (undamaged) and damaged ones is obvious. The area covered by the phase trajectory corresponding to the 40% damage case is significantly bigger than the one without damage or with less damage. Noise in the signal also significantly affects the reconstructed phase space. However, the topology of the phase trajectory is not changed although the reconstructed phase space becomes rough. As will be demonstrated later, the noise effect is not prominent to damage identification results using the proposed method based on response phase space changes. These observations indicate that the phase trajectories of dynamic responses change with structural damage, which therefore can be used to detect structural conditions.

caption.p: Response time series at measurement point 5 and the corresponding power spectrum: (a) time series with no noise, (b) power spectrum with no noise, (c) time series with 10% noise, and (d) power spectrum with 10% noise.
SD: single damage.
Shrinked phase space of recorded dynamic response at measurement 5: (a) the delay time is 1/40 of the first mode period and (b) the delay time is 1/2 of the first mode period.
SD: single damage.
Typical reconstructed phase space from data at measurement point 5: (a) without noise and (b) with 10% noise.
SD: single damage.

sec.p: Figure 14 shows the calculated CPST values along the arch using the numerically simulated dynamic responses of the arch without or with smeared noise of different levels. As shown, the CPST values at each measurement point (except the points 1 and 17 at the supports) increase with the damage, indicating that the damage at one location has influence on the dynamic responses of the entire arch. It should be noted that the CPST value at measurement point has only insignificant change since measurement point 9 is the node of mode shape 1 of the arch, which dominates the arch responses. This makes that the vibration amplitude of measurement 9 is much smaller than that of the other measurement points. This phenomenon also occurs in the subsequent experimental results. There is an obvious sharp peak at measurement point 5 in each curve corresponding to the damage location. This peak can be used to locate the damage. As shown in Figure 14(b) to (e), with the increase of the noise level, this sharp peak at measurement point 5 becomes less pronounced. However, even when the noise level is 15%, the peak CPST value at point 5 is still very prominent when the crack depth ratio is larger than 10%, indicating the damage location can still be identified. When the crack-to-cross-section depth ratio is 10%, the sharp peak at measurement point 5 is not prominent when the noise level is more than 5%, indicating that the damage location might not be confidently identified although the damage existence can be identified, as will be discussed later in this article. Nonetheless, compared with those mode shape–based indicators, as shown in Figure 9, it is obvious that the CPST based on phase space is more reliable in identifying the damage with noise-contaminated data.

caption.p: Calculated CPST values for damage detection: (a) no noise, (b) 1% noise, (c) 5% noise, (d) 10% noise, and (e) 15% noise.
CPST: changes of phase space topology; SD: single damage.

sec.title: Identification of MDs
sec.p: To check the method in identifying MDs in the structure, dynamic responses of the example arch structure with various MD scenarios as listed in Table 2 subjected to an impact load are simulated. The simulated dynamic responses are used to identify the damage. The modal frequencies of the structure corresponding to the different MD scenarios are also calculated through modal analysis, and the results are given in Table 3.

caption.p: First four frequencies of MD scenarios

sec.p: As shown, except Mode 3, the vibration frequencies decrease with the damage, as expected. Mode 3 frequencies are not affected because again the two assumed damage locations coincide with the stationary point of this mode. As can be noted, although frequency decreases with damage, the reduction is relatively insignificant. When both crack depth ratios are 40%, the reduction in modal vibration frequencies is only −3.37%, −1.79%, and −1.08% for Modes 1, 2, and 4, respectively. These small vibration frequency reductions might make the damage not identifiable owing to the influences such as changing environmental conditions, ambient loading conditions, and measurement noise, as discussed earlier.

Using the frequencies of Mode 1, which dominates the arch responses, the time delay T corresponding to each damage level is calculated, and then the corresponding phase space is reconstructed. The calculated CPST from the simulated dynamic responses without and with different levels of noises is shown in Figure 15. As shown, both damages are confidently identified when the crack depth ratio is equal to or larger than 20%. The results indicate that phase space–based method can well identify MDs, even the measured dynamic responses are contaminated with noise.

caption.p: Calculated CPST values of structure with MD scenarios: (a) no noise, (b) 1% noise, (c) 5% noise, (d) 10% noise, and (e) 15% noise.
CPST: changes of phase space topology; MD: multiple damage.

sec.p: It is interesting to note that when there is only a SD, the damage is clearly identified, even the crack-to-thickness ratio is 10% irrespective of the noise levels. When there are two damages, the second damage is identified only when the crack-to-thickness ratio is larger than 20%, also irrespective of the noise levels. These observations indicate that the proposed method is insensitive to noise. However, when MDs exist in the structure with a dominant damage, the small damages might not be identified because the large damage governs the calculated CPST index.

sec.title: Comparison with modal-based methods
sec.p: To demonstrate the advantage of this proposed method, following compares the sensitivity of CPST index to damage with the commonly used modal data–based indices in the literature. The damage indicators discussed earlier are normalized and compared in this section. The normalization of each damage indicator is defined as follows

where the superscripts u and d refer to undamaged and damaged conditions, respectively, and
cur
refers to the mode curvature difference. The modal-based indicator ECOMAC and flexibility change rate are the normalized indices; therefore, they are directly compared. Figure 16 shows the normalized values of different indicators at the damage location (e.g. measurement point 5 in SD described in section “SD detection”) corresponding to the different damage levels. As shown, CPST is the most sensitive indicator to damage, followed by the mode shape curvature difference. At an arbitrary undamaged location of the arch (e.g. measurement point 12), CPST is also very sensitive to damage as compared to the modal-based indicators. This observation indicates that the CPST indicator can be used to identify damage existence, even the measurement point is far away from the damage locations. To locate damage, however, as the results presented in sections “SD detection,” and “Identification of MDs,” it is necessary to have a sensor placed near the damage. This is a limitation of the current CPST indicator, and further research is deemed necessary to overcome this shortcoming. As shown, with the damage level increasing, the values of CPST near the damaged location and undamaged location all increase. This trend can probably be used to quantify the damage. However, it is believed that a baseline CPST value for each structure is needed to quantify the damage, and this baseline value varies from structure to structure. The challenge is that, as for many other damage indicators, such a baseline value is not straightforward to obtain. Further research is also necessary to find a straightforward and reliable means to quantify damage using phase space–based parameters. Nonetheless, the above-mentioned results demonstrate that CPST is far more sensitive to damage in a structure than any modal-based indicator, and like vibration frequency, it is a global parameter as one measurement at any location on the structure will register the changes in the structure, even the measurement location is away from the damage. Therefore, CPST is a good candidate to be used in continuous online SHM to identify damage occurrence.

caption.p: Comparison of the values of the normalized CPST and modal-based indicators: (a) measurement point 5 near the damage; (b) measurement point 12 away from the damage.
CPST: changes of phase space topology; COMAC: coordinate modal assurance criteria; ECOMAC: enhanced coordinate modal assurance criteria.

sec.title: Experimental model
sec.p: To further verify the proposed method, dynamic tests on a circular arch model are carried out. The experimental model is shown in Figure 17. The boundary condition, physical properties, and dimensions are the same as those used in numerical simulation presented in section “Modal-based damage detection.” The strain responses at 15 measurement points in addition to the two boundary ones along the midline of upper surface of the arch were measured with strain gauges. SD and MDs were designed, and crack was made by cutting the structural model with a very thin saw. The crack depth was also increased as those in numerical simulations, as defined in Table 2. A hammer was used to exert the impact excitation, and the responses were measured by the test system TMR-200 (developed by the Testing Institute, Tokyo, Japan). It should be noted that in the experimental tests, strain instead of acceleration was measured. Since the CPST indicator is obtained from phase space of the dynamic response time histories, in theory using either the strain measurement or acceleration measurement will lead to the same results.

caption.p: Photographs of experimental circular arch model.

sec.title: Frequencies
sec.p: The first four natural frequencies obtained from experiment are given in Table 4. As can be noticed, all the modal frequencies reduce with the damage, but the reduction, especially the Mode 3 frequency, is insignificant, even when the damage is very significant, that is, the crack depth is 40% of the thickness of the arch cross section. This observation is consistent with that obtained from numerical result, indicating that the natural vibration frequencies are not sensitive to crack damage. Therefore, although vibration frequencies are easily and reliably measured, they might not be able to detect damage if used alone in structural damage identification analysis.

caption.p: First four natural frequencies (hertz) obtained from experimental tests and their reductions with damage

fn.p: SD: single damage; MD: multiple damage.

sec.title: Damage detection using proposed method
sec.p: Figure 18 shows the measured time histories at measurement point 12 of the structure corresponding to the SD scenarios and the respective power spectrum. It can be observed in power spectrum that Mode 1 dominates the arch responses. Hence, the time delay is chosen according to Mode 1 period for phase space reconstruction, as described earlier.

caption.p: (a) Response time series at measurement point 12 under different damage scenarios and (b) the corresponding power spectrum.
SD: single damage.

sec.p: Figure 19 shows the reconstructed phase spaces of measured dynamic responses at two points when structure suffers a SD at the left damage location, as shown in Figure 10, with different damage levels. As shown, the topologies of phase spaces under different damage levels are different, and this phenomenon is more obvious near the damage location. This observation is also similar to that from the numerical result.

caption.p: Typical reconstructed phase space under different damage levels with a SD: (a) measurement point 12 and (b) measurement point 5.
SD: single damage.

sec.p: Based on the reconstructed phase spaces of measured dynamic responses at different points corresponding to the SD and MD scenarios, the CPST values are calculated. The results are shown in Figure 20. It can be observed that both SD and MDs are successfully identified with the phase space–based indicator CPST. It is also obvious that the CPST value of each measurement point increases with the damage, indicating that the damage at one location has influence on the dynamic responses of the entire structure. This is further observed in Figure 21, where the CPST values at measurement points 5 (near the damaged location 1) and 14 (near the damaged location 2) and measurement point 12 (undamaged location) corresponding to the different damage levels are shown. It is obvious that the CPST values of dynamic responses measured at any point on the structure increase quickly with structural damage, with those near the damage location increase faster. These observations are consistent with those obtained from numerical simulation results and demonstrate that CPST is a good indicator to identify damage existence, even the measurement points are away from the damaged locations. If a sufficient number of measurement points are used, it is also possible to locate the damage, and even quantify the damage.

caption.p: CPST curves of the arch under different damage scenarios: (a) SD scenarios and (b) MD scenarios.
CPST: changes of phase space topology; SD: single damage; MD: multiple damage.
Development of CPST with damage level: (a) SD scenario and (b) MD scenario.
CPST: changes of phase space topology; SD: single damage; MD: multiple damage.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article presents a new method based on reconstructed phase space of measured dynamic responses on structures for identification of structural damage. A new parameter based on geometry changes of the reconstructed phase space trajectories of the measured vibration signals, named CPST, is proposed for damage identification. To demonstrate the method, both numerical simulations and experimental tests of dynamic responses of an example arch structure with different imposed damages are carried out. The dynamic responses are then used to identify structural damages using the traditional modal-based methods, as well as the proposed method in this study. It is found that the proposed damage indicator CPST is a lot more sensitive to structural damage and less sensitive to noise than modal-based parameters. Both the numerical and experimental results demonstrate that the CPST indicator successfully identifies damage existence and possibly damage locations. It is very sensitive to structural damage, even the measurement point is away from the damaged locations. Therefore, it can be used to identify damage occurrence. This new CPST indicator is a better candidate for continuous online SHM than modal-based indicators.
